meanings.definition: To keep back or save for future use.
meanings.sent1: I will reserve some snacks for the movie later.
meanings.sent2: She likes to reserve some money for emergencies.
meanings.sent3: Please reserve your excitement for the surprise party.
meanings.sent4: He tends to reserve his emotions like a tightly sealed jar.
meanings.sent5: The squirrel will reserve nuts for the winter in its cozy burrow.

meanings.definition: A supply of something that is stored for future use.
meanings.sent1: The hotel has a reserve of extra towels for guests.
meanings.sent2: The country keeps a reserve of food for times of need.
meanings.sent3: The reserve of jokes in his mind seemed endless.
meanings.sent4: Her kindness was a reserve that never seemed to run out.
meanings.sent5: The reserve of energy in the battery kept the flashlight bright.

meanings.definition: To refrain from using or disclosing.
meanings.sent1: He decided to reserve his opinion on the matter.
meanings.sent2: She will reserve her comments until after the meeting.
meanings.sent3: The magician will reserve the secret of his trick.
meanings.sent4: She tried to reserve her laughter but couldn't help it.
meanings.sent5: The detective will reserve revealing the suspect's name for later.

meanings.definition: A place set aside for a specific purpose.
meanings.sent1: The park has a reserve for picnics and gatherings.
meanings.sent2: The library has a reserve section for rare books.
meanings.sent3: The secret club had a reserve room for special meetings.
meanings.sent4: The garden had a reserve of flowers for the annual festival.
meanings.sent5: The museum had a reserve of artifacts waiting to be displayed.
